overview_of_class: 'Brain training' games can improve your memory. Gun control reduces violence. Racial protest leads to improved race relations on college campuses. Trigger warnings are good for students. Acupuncture heals. Is each claim true or false? The answers are too often based on anecdote and intuition, instead of empirical evidence. This course will teach you to evaluate the evidence of others - and to marshal your own - across science, politics, society, health, education and industry. We will provide an overview of three types of evidence: the type of qualitative interviews that social scientists use to understand the experience of racial bias and discrimination, the type of ?big data' analyses that political campaigns use to target voters, and the type of randomized controlled trials that Google uses to measure your preferences. Assignments and readings will focus on real¬world questions drawn from newspaper articles, podcasts, and op-eds (e.g., http://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate), as well as the research literature and data science media (e.g., www.fivethirtyeight.com) that collect and evaluate empirical evidence.
